message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that clenching the fist increases the intensity of the murmur suggests that it is related to changes in pressure in the heart. The most likely cause of this is a defect in the ventricular septum, which would cause a left-to-right shunt and increase blood flow through the pulmonary valve, leading to the murmur. Fusion of the right and left coronary leaflets would not cause a murmur. A defect in the atrial septum would cause a right-to-left shunt and potentially lead to a murmur, but it would not increase in intensity with fist clenching. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close would not cause a murmur in this location.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the murmur intensity increases with a forceful fist clench suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Additionally, this is the most common congenital heart defect in children. The other options do not typically cause an increase in murmur intensity with fist clenching.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The “clenched fist” maneuver is used to increase systemic vascular resistance and can increase the intensity of a murmur associated with ventricular septal defects. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient’s auscultation findings is a defect in the ventricular septum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s auscultation findings suggest a ventricular septal defect (VSD). When the child clenches her fist, it leads to an increase in systemic vascular resistance, which causes an increase in left ventricular pressure, leading to a bigger pressure difference across the VSD and thus, an increase in the intensity of the murmur. Options A and D are not related to VSD, and option B would result in an atrial septal defect murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the intensity of the murmur increases when the patient clenches her fist suggests that it is related to increased afterload on the left ventricle. This is a characteristic of a ventricular septal defect (VSD), as it allows blood to flow from the high-pressure left ventricle to the lower-pressure right ventricle. Fusion of the right and left coronary leaflets is a cause of aortic stenosis, which would not be affected by fist clenching. Defects in the atrial septum would not cause a murmur. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close leads to a patent ductus arteriosus, which would also not be affected by fist clenching.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased intensity of the murmur upon hand clenching points towards a ventricular septal defect (VSD). The other options do not have such a characteristic feature.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clenched fist maneuver tests for dynamic changes in the cardiac murmur intensity. Among the options, only a ventricular septal defect can cause a holosystolic murmur with increased intensity during the clenched fist maneuver.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that clenching a fist increases the intensity of the murmur suggests the presence of a VSD, which causes increased blood flow across the ventricular septum when the child increases systemic vascular resistance by clenching her fist. Options A and B are not related to the ventricular septum, and failure of the ductus arteriosus to close causes a different type of murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increase of intensity of murmur with forceful fist clenching is consistent with Valsalva maneuver, which increases intrathoracic pressure, decreasing venous return and left ventricular volume. This would increase the amount of shunting through a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation findings is a defect in the ventricular septum (option C).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the intensity of the murmur increases when the patient clenches her fist suggests a VSD (ventricular septal defect), which is the only option that causes an increase in blood flow and pressure with increased systemic vascular resistance, such as during a fist-clenching maneuver.
